properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Westerly winds will reach up to 90 kilometres per hour today. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T06:43:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-22T14:44:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2422776727.2020
Area: Kangirsuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS AND VERNON The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-23T08:55:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-22T16:56:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1854810129.2020
Area: North Okanagan, Bulkley Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will give snow to the South Peace River region starting this evening. The snow will persist through tonight and is expected to taper off to a few flurries late Monday. Total snow accumulations of 10 to 20 cm can be expected with higher amounts near the Rockies. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T14:47:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-22T22:48:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1669625951.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm with higher amounts possible in some areas. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except possibly up to 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: the Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop late in the day Tuesday, and will then become accompanied by strong northerly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow early Wednesday morning. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strong winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. At this time there is some uncertainty regarding where the highest snowfall amounts will occur. Additional information will be provided as details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-23T17:52:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T01:53:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3765933764.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight and Monday morning. Snow, heavy at times, and blowing snow will develop late this evening and continue overnight. Snow will taper to flurries or end by late Monday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are likely with the heaviest snow falling near midnight. Travel is expected to be hazardous tonight due to heavy snow. Quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T17:21:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T01:22:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1771553580.2020
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain and wind on Tuesday. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 60 to 80 km/h. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow will start early Tuesday morning and then change to rain by late morning or early afternoon over mainland Nova Scotia. The snow will persist into the afternoon over Cape Breton before mixing with rain. The rain may become heavy at times over southwestern Nova Scotia. Current indications suggest that rainfall warnings for 25 mm or more may be required for southwestern Nova Scotia while snowfall warnings of 15 cm or more remain possible over eastern Nova Scotia. There remains some uncertainty with the track of this system which could affect the type and amount of precipitation expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T17:22:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T01:23:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3277333141.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow will begin overnight as a low pressure system develops in central Alberta. Snow will continue to fall throughout the day on Monday, before finally tapering off early Tuesday morning. Note that for the Whitecourt region, it is areas north of Whitecourt that are expected to receive snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm. This warning may need to be expanded to other regions as the system develops. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-23T13:50:14-00:00
